docs.title: Forensic
docs.text: Forensics is the application of scientific methods and techniques to investigate crimes and gather evidence that can stand up in a court of law. It spans multiple disciplines, including digital forensics, forensic biology, forensic chemistry, and forensic anthropology. By methodically analyzing data and artifacts, forensic experts play a crucial role in solving crimes and ensuring justice.

docs.title: Tools
docs.text:
• dd.exe - dd.exe is a Windows port of the classic Unix disk cloning and imaging tool.
  • winpmem.exe - WinPmem is a powerful memory acquisition tool designed for Windows systems.
  • TestDisk - TestDisk checks the partition and boot sectors of your disks. It is very useful in recovering lost partitions.
  • PhotoRec - PhotoRec is file data recovery software designed to recover lost pictures from digital camera memory or even hard disks.
  • Volatility - The Volatility Framework is a completely open collection of tools, implemented in Python under the GNU General Public License, for the extraction of digital artifacts from volatile memory (RAM) samples.

docs.title: dd
docs.text:
Source | Download

dd.exe if=\\?\Device\Harddisk(X)\Partition0 of=Z:\disk.raw --progress bs=17408

docs.title: WinPmem
docs.text:
Source | Download

winpmem.exe --output memory_dump.raw

docs.text:
Source

sudo apt install testdisk

testdisk <file>

docs.title: PhotoRec
docs.text:
Source

sudo apt install testdisk

photorec <file>

docs.title: Volatility 2
docs.text:
Source

git clone https://github.com/volatilityfoundation/volatility.git
sudo wget https://bootstrap.pypa.io/pip/2.7/get-pip.py
sudo apt install python2.7 python2.7-dev
sudo python2.7 get-pip.py
sudo python2.7 -m pip install --upgrade setuptools
sudo python2.7 -m pip install pycrypto
sudo python2.7 -m pip install distorm3==3.4.4

Modify shebang to #!/usr/bin/python2.7 and enable execution

Fistly, you need to get the image profile :

./vol.py -f <file> imageinfo

./vol.py -f <file> --profile=<profile_name> <cmd>

Some commands :

  • filescan : Pool scanner for file objects
  • svcscan : Scan for Windows services
  • pslist : Print all running processes by following the EPROCESS lists
  • mftparser : Scans for and parses potential MFT entries
  • memdump -p <pid> --dump-dir <output_directory> :
  • hivelist : Print list of registry hives.
  • printkey : Print a registry key, and its subkeys and values
  • envars :

docs.title: Checksum & Date & Archive
docs.text:
md5sum <file> && date
sha256sum <file> && date
zip -r -0 <archive_name>.zip <file_to_zip>
tar -cf <archive_name>.tar <file_to_zip>

docs.title: Memprocfs
docs.text:
Source

memprocfs -f <image> -forensic 1 -mount <directory>

docs.title: Steps of forensic
docs.text:
1. Network Isolation
  2. Initial Assessment (Crisis management: You, IT Director, Manager, First Responder)
  3. Time Synchronization Verification (Check watches and system clocks)
  4. RAM Dump Acquisition
  5. RAM Dump Integrity Verification (MD5 checksum of RAM.dmp)
  6. Disk Image Acquisition
  7. Disk Image Integrity Verification (MD5 checksum of Disk.dmp)
  8. Archiving (Uncompressed .tar format)
  9. Archive Integrity Verification (MD5 checksum)
  10. Start RAM and Disk Analysis
  11. Final Integrity Verification (Checksum validation)
  12. Forensic Report Preparation
  13. Conclusions and Recommendations

docs.title: Generate new ssh key
docs.text: $ ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"

docs.title: Go back to a commit
docs.text:
Go back to a commit with staged changes with the following command :

$ git reset --soft <commit hash>

Go back to a commit without the staged changes with the following command :

$ git reset --hard <commit hash>

Notes that a force-pushing will be required to override the history.

docs.title: Edit commits information
docs.text:
Updating the last Commit

You can change your past commit information such as author, message, etc..

$ git commit --amend

The command above loads the previous commit message into an editor session, where you can make changes to the message, save those changes and exit. When you save and close the editor, the editor writes a new commit containing that updated commit message and makes it your new last commit.

Updating Multiple Commits

To modify multiple commits, combine commit --amend with rebase:

$ git rebase -i <commit hash>

When using interactive rebase, you will be presented with a list of commits. You can choose actions (commands) to apply to each commit. To amend a commit, use the edit command.

After saving and exiting the interactive editor, Git will stop at the commit marked for editing. You might see something like this:

$ git rebase -i HEAD~3
Stopped at f7f3f6d... Change my name a bit
You can amend the commit now, with

       git commit --amend

Once you're satisfied with your changes, run

       git rebase --continue

Repeat the process for each edit until the rebase is complete.

Notes:

  • Force-pushing (git push --force) will be required after amending or rebasing.
  • <commit hash> can be replaced by HEAD~x (e.g. HEAD~3) to get the last x commits.

docs.title: Workflows
docs.text: GitHub workflows are automated processes defined in YAML files that enable developers to streamline tasks such as code building, testing, deployment, and custom automation based on events like code pushes or pull requests.

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
Your workflows must be located in .github/workflows directory.

.
├── .git/
    └── ...
├── .github/
    └── workflows/
        └── <your_workflow>.yml
...

docs.title: Yaml file structure
docs.text:
To set up a valid GitHub workflow, you must include some required parameters in your YAML file. Below are key parameters and their descriptions:

name : The name of the workflow. This is a descriptive identifier for the workflow that appears in the GitHub Actions UI.

on : Specifies the events that trigger the workflow. Common events are push, pull_request, and custom events.

on.push.branches : Specifies which branches trigger the workflow on push events.

env : Defines environment variables that are available to all jobs and steps in the workflow.

jobs : A collection of jobs to be executed in the workflow. Each job can run on a specific environment and container.

jobs.<your_job>.runs-on : Specifies the type of machine to run the job on. Common options are ubuntu-latest, windows-latest, and macos-latest.

jobs.<your_job>.container : Defines the container environment for the job. This is useful for running jobs in a custom Docker image.

jobs.<your_job>.steps : Defines the individual steps to be executed in the job. Each step can run commands, use actions, or set up environments.

To fail a job's step manually, you can exit 1 when running a command.

Here is a structure of a github workflow yaml file :

name: <workflow_name>

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - <branch1>
      - <branch2>
  pull_request:
    branches:
      - <branch1>
      - <branch2>

env:
  ENV_KEY: <value>

jobs:
  <your_job_name>:
    runs-on: <chosen_os>
    container:
      image: <chosen_image>
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
        with:
          fetch-depth: 0
      - name: <your_step_name_1>
        run: <your_command>
      - name: <your_step_name_2>
        timeout-minutes: 2
        run: <your_command>

  <your_job_2>:
  ...

Here is an exemple of a basic github workflow :

name: Makefile CI

on:
  push:
    branches: [ "main" ]
  pull_request:
    branches: [ "main" ]

jobs:
  build:

    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v4

    - name: configure
      run: ./configure

docs.title: Actions secrets
docs.text:
Secrets and variables allow you to manage reusable configuration data. Secrets are encrypted and are used for sensitive data.

You can found your secrets at Your Repository overview -> Settings -> Secrets and Variables -> Actions.

To call a secret you have to use this syntaxe : ${{ secrets.YOUR_SECRET }}.

More documentation on github.

docs.title: Create an user account
docs.text: pveam available --section system pveam download local debian-12-standard_12.7-1_amd64.tar.zst

docs.title: Rentrer dans un conteneur
docs.text:
pct enter <id>

a noter qu'il faut faire un : apt update && apt upgrade après toute install d'une nouveau conteneur

docs.title: pwndbg
docs.text:
pwndbg is an extension for gdb that provides many convenience features for reverse engineering and exploitation.

Repository: https://github.com/pwndbg/pwndbg

Install (one-line):

curl -qsL 'https://install.pwndbg.re' | sh -s -- -t pwndbg-gdb

Once installed, start gdb normally; pwndbg will load automatically and enhance the prompt, stack/heap views, and many helper commands.

docs.title: gdb (essential commands)
docs.text:
Common gdb commands and short explanations useful during exploit development:

# break at main (or another symbol)
break main


# disassemble 'main'
disass main


# list functions (grep a function name)
info functions <function_name>


# dump memory at the current stack pointer (200 bytes shown as hex-bytes)
x/<nbr>xb $rsp


# find which symbol owns an address
info symbol <address>

docs.title: Showing execution path (how the program runs)
docs.text:
common interactive workflow in gdb:

Start the program in gdb using run with desired arguments or input.

Use CTRL+C to interrupt execution at any point to inspect registers, memory and call stack.

Useful helper commands while debugging:

# show mapped memory areas for the current process (pwndbg provides 'vmmap')
vmmap


# show externally what shared libraries the target binary will use
ldd /path/to/challenge

docs.title: Ropper
docs.text:
ropper is a tool that finds gadgets in binaries and libraries (useful for building ROP chains).

Install:

pip install --user ropper

Use:

ropper --file <file>
# or search for a specific gadget pattern
ropper --file <file> --chain 'pop|ret'

docs.title: Finding functions inside a library
docs.text: nm -D /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 | grep " system"

docs.title: Running networked challenges (netcat example)
docs.text:
To run a challenge locally and listen for incoming connections (example):

# netcat listens on port 1337 and executes the binary for each connection
ncat -lvp 1337 -c './binary'

docs.title: Structure
docs.text:
src/ # Répertoire des sources
tests/ # Répertoire des tests
README.md # Fichier de description du projet
.pre-commit-config.yaml # Configuration de pre-commit
poetry.lock # Fichier de lock de poetry
pyproject.toml # Fichier de configuration de poetry
.gitignore # Fichier d'exclusion de git
.git/ # Répertoire de git
.idea/ # Répertoire de PyCharm
.venv/ # Répertoire de l'environnement virtuel

docs.title: Via pip :
docs.text: pip install poetry

docs.title: Via script :
docs.text: curl -sSL https://install.python-poetry.org | python3 -

docs.title: Init project
docs.text:
poetry new <project_name>

poetry init

docs.title: Install dependence
docs.text:
Add dependence

poetry add nom_du_paquet

Install all dependences

poetry install

docs.title: Mkdocs
docs.text: MkDocs is a fast, simple and downright gorgeous static site generator that's geared towards building project documentation. Documentation source files are written in Markdown, and configured with a single YAML configuration file.

docs.title: Marp
docs.text: Marp (also known as the Markdown Presentation Ecosystem) provides an intuitive experience for creating beautiful slide decks. You only have to focus on writing your story in a Markdown document.

docs.title: Ventoy
docs.text: Ventoy is an open source tool to create bootable USB drive for ISO/WIM/IMG/VHD(x)/EFI files. With ventoy, you don't need to format the disk over and over, you just need to copy the ISO/WIM/IMG/VHD(x)/EFI files to the USB drive and boot them directly.

docs.title: ASM X64
docs.text: https://x64.syscall.sh/

docs.title: Registry
docs.text: 64-bit 32 bits 16 bits Higher & Lower 8 bits RAX EAX AX AH / AL RBX EBX BX BH / BL RCX ECX CX CH / CL RDX EDX DX DH / DL RSI ESI SI SIL RBP EBP BP BPL RSP ESP SP SPL RDI EDI DI DIL R8 R8D R8W R8B R9 R9D R9W R9B R10 R10D R10W R10B R11 R11D R11W R11B R12 R12D R12W R12B R13 R13D R13W R13B R14 R14D R14W R14B R15 R15D R15W R15B

docs.title: Data Definition Directives
docs.text: Data Definition Directives in assembly language are compiler directives that allocate and initialize memory for variables in a program. These directives define variables with specific sizes and values in the .data or .bss section of an assembly program. They help reserve space for storing numbers, characters, floating-point values, and pointers in memory.

docs.title: Data Reservation Directives in .data
docs.text: Directive Meaning Size (Bytes) Example Usage DB (Define Byte) Reserves 1 byte 1 byte var1 DB 0x12 (1 byte) DW (Define Word) Reserves 1 word 2 bytes var2 DW 0x1234 (2 bytes) DD (Define Doubleword) Reserves 1 doubleword 4 bytes var3 DD 0x12345678 (4 bytes) DQ (Define Quadword) Reserves 1 quadword 8 bytes var4 DQ 0x123456789ABCDEF0 (8 bytes) DT (Define Ten Bytes) Reserves 1 ten-byte value 10 bytes var5 DT 123.456 (used for floating-point values in some cases)

docs.title: Data Reservation Directives in .bss
docs.text: Directive Meaning Size (Bytes) Example Usage RESB (Reserve Byte) Reserves N bytes 1 byte buffer RESB 100 (Reserves 100 bytes) RESW (Reserve Word) Reserves N words 2 bytes array RESW 10 (Reserves 10 × 2 bytes = 20 bytes) RESD (Reserve Doubleword) Reserves N doublewords 4 bytes arr RESD 5 (Reserves 5 × 4 bytes = 20 bytes) RESQ (Reserve Quadword) Reserves N quadwords 8 bytes data RESQ 3 (Reserves 3 × 8 bytes = 24 bytes) REST (Reserve Ten Bytes) Reserves N ten-byte values 10 bytes bigData REST 2 (Reserves 20 bytes)

docs.title: Arithmetic instructions
docs.text:
add rax, 1    ; Adds 1 to RAX.
sub rax, rdi  ; Subtracts the value of RDI from RAX and stores the result in RAX.
mul rsi       ; Multiplies RAX by RSI and stores the result in RAX.
div rbx       ; Divides RAX by RBX, storing the quotient in RAX and the remainder in RDX.

and rax, rcx  ; Performs a bitwise AND between RAX and RCX, storing the result in RAX.
or rdx, 1     ; Performs a bitwise OR between RDX and 1, storing the result in RDX.
xor rsi, rsi  ; Performs a bitwise XOR between RSI and itself (zeroing RSI).
not rbx       ; Inverts every bit of RBX.

docs.title: Read
docs.text:
• rax Syscall number (0 for read)
  • rdi File descriptor (0 for stdin)
  • rsi Buffer to store the input
  • rdx Number of bytes to read

Return : Number of bytes read in rax, 0 if EOF

section .bss
    buffer resb 10  ; Reserve 10 bytes for input
...
    mov rax, 0       ; sys_read
    mov rdi, 0       ; stdin
    mov rsi, buffer  ; buffer address
    mov rdx, 10      ; read up to 10 bytes
    syscall

docs.title: Write
docs.text:
• rax Syscall number (1 for write)
  • rdi File descriptor (1 for standard output)
  • rsi Pointer to the string (buffer) to write
  • rdx Number of bytes to write

Return : Number of bytes written in rax

Example: Writing message to stdout

    mov rax, 1         ; sys_write
    mov rdi, 1         ; stdout
    mov rsi, msg       ; message address
    mov rdx, msg_len   ; message length
    syscall

docs.title: Open
docs.text:
• rax Syscall number (2 for open)
  • rdi Pointer to filename
  • rsi Flags (0 = read-only, 1 = write-only, 2 = read/write)
  • rdx File permissions (only if creating a file)

Return : File descriptor in rax

Example: Open a file for reading

    mov rax, 2        ; sys_open
    mov rdi, filename ; file name
    mov rsi, 0        ; O_RDONLY
    syscall

Example: Creating or append a file

    mov rax, 2  ; sys_open
    mov rdi, filename  ; file name
    mov rsi, 0x441 ; O_WRONLY | O_CREAT | O_APPEND
    mov rdx, 0o666 ; rw-rw-rw-
    syscall

docs.title: Close
docs.text:
• rax Syscall number (3 for close)
  • rdi File descriptor to close

Example: Closing a file descriptor (fd)

    mov rax, 3  ; sys_close
    mov rdi, fd ; file descriptor
    syscall

docs.title: Exit
docs.text:
• rax Syscall number (60 for exit)
  • rdi Exit status (0 = success, nonzero = error)

Example: Exit with status 0

    mov rax, 60  ; sys_exit
    xor rdi, rdi ; exit(0)
    syscall

docs.title: Socket
docs.text:
• rax Syscall number (41 for socket)
  • rdi Address family (2 for AF_INET)
  • rsi Socket type (1 for SOCK_STREAM)
  • rdx Protocol (0 for default)

Return : Socket file descriptor in rax

Example: Create an IPv4 TCP socket

    mov rax, 41     ; sys_socket
    mov rdi, 2      ; AF_INET
    mov rsi, 1      ; SOCK_STREAM
    xor rdx, rdx    ; protocol 0
    syscall

docs.title: Bind
docs.text:
• rax Syscall number (49 for bind)
  • rdi Socket file descriptor
  • rsi Pointer to sockaddr structure
  • rdx Size of the sockaddr structure

Example: Bind a socket

section .data
    sockaddr_in:
        .sin_family dw 2 ; AF_INET
        .sin_port   dw 0x3905 ; Port 1337 (little-endian: 0x0539)
        .sin_addr   dd 0 ; INADDR_ANY (0.0.0.0)
...
    mov rax, 49      ; sys_bind
    mov rdi, sockfd  ; socket file descriptor
    mov rsi, sockaddr; pointer to sockaddr structure
    mov rdx, 16      ; size of sockaddr_in
    syscall

docs.title: Recvfrom
docs.text:
• rax Syscall number (45 for recvfrom)
  • rdi Socket file descriptor
  • rsi Pointer to buffer for received data
  • rdx Maximum number of bytes to receive
  • r10 Flags
  • r8 Pointer to sender’s address
  • r9 Pointer to sender’s address length

Return : Number of bytes received in rax

Example: Receive data from a socket

    mov rax, 45      ; sys_recvfrom
    mov rdi, sockfd  ; socket descriptor
    mov rsi, buffer  ; buffer address
    mov rdx, 1024    ; max bytes to receive
    xor r10, r10     ; flags = 0
    xor r8, r8       ; no sender address
    xor r9, r9       ; no sender length
    syscall

docs.title: Set a Specific Video Bitrate
docs.text:
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -b:v 2000k -c:v libx264 -c:a copy output.mp4
  • -b:v 2000k : Sets video bitrate to 2000 kbps.
  • -c:v libx264 : Ensures H.264 encoding.

docs.title: Extract a Single Frame at a Specific Time
docs.text:
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -ss 00:00:05 -vframes 1 output.png
  • -ss 00:00:05 : Seeks to 5 seconds.
  • -vframes 1 : Extracts one frame.
  • output.png : Saves as a PNG (can be .jpg or .bmp).

docs.title: Extract/Cut video
docs.text:
ffmpeg -i input.mp4 -ss 00:00:00 -to 00:01:30 -c copy output.mp4
  • -ss 00:00:00 : Sets the start time (hh:mm:ss), in this case, from 0:00.
  • -to 00:01:30 : Sets the end time at 1 minute 30 seconds.

docs.title: How to configure a hostname on a Linux
docs.text:
Modify the system's name temporarily

hostname demo.example.com

Modify the system's name permanently

hostnamectl set-hostname demo.example.com

You can confirm this entry by displaying the /etc/hostname file contents.

docs.title: Check what your network manager:
docs.text: ps aux | grep -E 'dhcpcd|NetworkManager|systemd-networkd'

docs.title: DHCPCD
docs.text:
Edit the file in /etc/dhcpcd.conf

Add this section :

interface wlan0
static ip_address=192.168.x.x/24
static routers=192.168.x.x

Restart or reboot:

sudo systemctl restart dhcpcd

docs.title: NetworkManager
docs.text:
Using nmcli :

nmcli connection show
nmcli connection modify <YourWifiConnection> ipv4.method manual ipv4.addresses 192.168.x.x/24 ipv4.gateway 192.168.x.x
nmcli connection modify <YourWifiConnection> ipv4.dns-priority -1
nmcli connection down <YourWifiConnection> && nmcli connection up <YourWifiConnection>

Mannualy :

Edit the file in /etc/NetworkManager/system-connections/<YourWifiProfile>

In the [ipv4] section:

[ipv4]
method=manual
address1=192.168.x.x/24,192.168.x.x

Save and apply:

sudo chmod 600 /etc/NetworkManager/system-connections/MyWifiConnection.nmconnection
sudo systemctl restart NetworkManager

docs.title: Manual configuration (on Ubuntu-based systems)
docs.text:
Edit the network configuration:

sudo nano /etc/network/interfaces

Add or modify the following lines:

allow-hotplug ethX
iface ethX inet static
    address 192.168.x.x
    netmask 255.255.255.0
    gateway 192.168.x.x

Restart networking:

sudo systemctl restart networking

docs.title: File permissions
docs.text:
drwxr-xr-x 2 owner group *.*K ****-**-** **:** docs
-rw-r--r-- 1 owner group *.*K ****-**-** **:** document.txt
lrwxrwxrwx 2 owner group *.*K ****-**-** **:** team.docs

File type ; User ; Group ; Everyone

File types :

  • d Directory
  • - Regular file
  • l Symbolic Link

Permissions digits :

  • r (read): 4
  • w (write): 2
  • x (execute): 1

docs.title: Change folder owner
docs.text: chown -R <user>:<group> <folder_path>

docs.title: Configure SSH key authentification based
docs.text:
Make sure your server have the file .ssh/authorized_keys in the home of the user.

Generate a key for the client :

ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"

You can then use ssh-copy-id [-i <key.pub>] <user>@<server_ip> to copy the key to the server authorized_keys

In the server : Edit /etc/ssh/sshd_config:

And change these :

...
PubkeyAuthentication yes
...
AuthorizedKeysFile      .ssh/authorized_keys .ssh/authorized_keys2
...
PasswordAuthentication no
...

docs.title: Crontab
docs.text:
Create a crontab :

crontab -e

Path of crontabs is in /var/spool/cron/crontabs.

docs.title: Connection shell
docs.text: You can configure a user's login shell by editing the /etc/passwd file. To allow shell access, specify a valid shell such as /bin/bash, /bin/sh, or any other available shell on the system. To prevent a user from logging in with a shell, set their shell to /usr/sbin/nologin.

docs.title: Create service account
docs.text: useradd -d <home_directory> -s <shell_path> -r <username>

docs.title: Generate ssl key
docs.text:
• Key generation : genpkey
  • Certificat request : req (-x509)
  • Certificat signing : x509
  • Verify certification chain : verify

Note: Since 2016, Firefox has disabled the Domain Name; it must now be done with a SAN (v1).

Model generation v3.

docs.title: RCA
docs.text:
Generate RCA key :

openssl genpkey -algorithm RSA -pkeyopt rsa_keygen_bits:4096 -out rca.key

Create RCA configuration :

[req]
prompt = no
distinguished_name = dn
req_extensions = ext

[dn]
CN = <Commun Name>
O = <Organization>

[ext]
subjectAltName = DNS:*.<my-domain>

NB : You can precise DNS or IP

Generate RCA certificat :

openssl req -x509 -key rca.key -out rca.crt -days 365 -config conf_rca

Check certificat:

openssl x509 -nout -text -in rca.crt

docs.title: ICA (Intermediate CA)
docs.text:
Generate ICA key :

openssl genpkey -algorithm RSA -pkeyopt rsa_keygen_bits:4096 -out ica.key

Create ICA configuration :

[req]
prompt = no
distinguished_name = dn
req_extensions = ext
x509_extensions = ext

[dn]
CN = <Commun Name>
O = <Organization>

[ext]
basicConstraints = CA:true
subjectAltName = DNS:*.<my-domain>

On a ajouter x509_extensions = ext

Generate ICA certificat :

openssl req -x509 -key ica.key -out ica.crt -CA rca.crt -CAkey rca.key -days 365 -config conf_ica

-CA : auto qui va signer ce cert

Vertifier que la chaine est valide :

openssl verify -CAfile rca.crt ica.crt

Check certificat:

openssl x509 -nout -text -in ica.crt

docs.title: CA Web
docs.text:
Generate CA key :

openssl genpkey -algorithm RSA -pkeyopt rsa_keygen_bits:4096 -out web.key

Create CA configuration :

[req]
prompt = no
distinguished_name = dn
req_extensions = ext
x509_extensions = ext

[dn]
CN = <Commun Name>
O = <Organization>

[ext]
basicConstraints = CA:false
subjectAltName = DNS:web.<my-domain>

Generate CA certificat :

openssl req -x509 -key web.key -out web.crt -CA ica.crt -CAkey ica.key -days 365 -config conf_web

Verify full chain:

cat ica.crt rca.crt > chain.crt
openssl verify -CAfile chain.crt web.crt

docs.title: 1. Start Radare2 in Debug Mode
docs.text:
r2 -d <binary>

Launches Radare2 with the specified binary in debug mode (similar to gdb ./binary).

docs.title: 2. Analyze the Binary
docs.text:
aaa

Performs auto analysis of the binary — finds functions, basic blocks, symbols, etc. You can also use:

  • aa — basic analysis
  • aaa — deeper analysis (recommended for most cases)

docs.title: 3. Enter Visual Mode
docs.text:
v

Enters visual mode for interactive inspection of code and memory. Use these shortcuts inside visual mode:

  • p — change view (disassembly, hex, graph, etc.)
  • V — visual graph mode
  • q — quit visual mode

docs.title: 4. Inspect Functions and Code
docs.text:
pdf

Prints the disassembly of the current function.

You can also use:

pd <n>

to print <n> instructions from the current address.

docs.title: 5. Set Breakpoints
docs.text:
db <address>

Sets a breakpoint at the specified address. Example:

db main

sets a breakpoint at the main() function.

docs.title: 6. Continue Execution
docs.text:
dc

Continue program execution until the next breakpoint or program termination.

Other useful commands:

  • ds — step into (like stepi in GDB)
  • dso — step over (skip function calls)
  • dr — show registers
  • px — dump memory in hex
  • pxw — dump memory as 32-bit words

docs.title: 7. Common Visual Mode Shortcuts
docs.text: Key Description v Enter visual mode V Visual graph mode p Change display mode s Seek (move to address) / Search pattern db Set breakpoint dc Continue execution q Quit visual mode

docs.title: Exiting
docs.text: Exiting :q Close file :qa Close all files :w Save :wq / :x Save and close file ZZ Save and quit :q!/ ZQ Quit without checking changes
